titleStmt.title: Beyond rational choice: A typology of urban discovery

analytic.title: Beyond rational choice: A typology of urban discovery

biblStruct.note: Accepted for publication in Tourism Management.

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: As the internet, smartphones, and review pla3orms transform how travelers discover urban a8rac9ons, understanding this process is cri9cal for harnessing a sustainable urban a8rac9on space.

Yet urban discovery remains poorly understood and exis9ng research is fragmented. To address this gap, we adapt Leiper's tourist a8rac9on systems framework to study urban discovery. Our grounded theory analysis on 126 interviews resulted in five dis9nct discovery modes: instrumental-ra9onal, gowith-the-flow, social, flaneur, and habitual. Besides richly describing these modes, we iden9fy personal, social, contextual, demographic, and affec9ve factors influencing them. We illustrate how playful discovery modes-go-with-the-flow, social, and flaneur-are compa9ble, leading to mixed discovery modes, while the remaining modes are incompa9ble. These findings challenge the dominance of ra9onal choice models by revealing a broader spectrum of discovery behaviors. They also provide a founda9on for designing a more inclusive urban a8rac9on content space and offer strategic implica9ons for urban a8rac9on management.

div.head: Introduc4on
div.p: The tourism and hospitality landscape has been transformed by digitaliza9on. Just two decades ago, travelers in Europe seldom used the internet for trip planning (Gursoy & McCleary, 2004). In stark contrast, recent studies find that today's travelers rely almost exclusively on digital tools (Gursoy et al., 2017;H. Kim et al., 2015;Xiang et al., 2015). The primary source of informa9on has shieed from guidebooks and flyers to pla3orms like TripAdvisor and Google, fundamentally changing how travel content is created and consumed (Navío-Marco et al., 2018). These pla3orms centralize user-generated content, such as reviews and ra9ngs, revolu9onizing how consumers discover hotels, restaurants, and a8rac9ons (Buhalis & Law, 2008;Xiang & Fesenmaier, 2020). As powerful actors, they direct tourist a8en9on, shape expecta9ons, and ul9mately influence choices (Sparks et al., 2013;Xiang & Gretzel, 2010). This power compels managers to adopt new strategies, from craeing "Instagrammable" décor to offering incen9ves for five-star reviews (Gössling et al., 2018;So9riadis, 2017). Despite this profound transforma9on, significant gaps remain in our understanding. Li8le is known about how this new digital environment has reshaped the process of urban discovery, nor what cons9tutes effec9ve marke9ng strategy within it (Hollebeek & Macky, 2019). This study addresses these ques9ons by focusing on urban a8rac9ons-defined here as shops, hospitality venues, and other city-based ac9vi9es. We focus on these sites because they are central to urban life, shaping decisions to visit or reside in a city while also determining the socio-economic outcomes for local communi9es. Furthermore, the city provides an interes9ng context to study the discovery of a8rac9ons because they suffer choice overload (Ashworth & Page, 2011;Edwards et al., 2008;Page & Duignan, 2023).

To study urban discovery, we build on Leiper's (1990) conceptual framework about tourist a8rac9on systems. Leiper (1990) theorized that an a8rac9on is not merely a physical "nucleus" (such as a restaurant or museum) but instead arises from the connec9on of three elements: a person with leisure needs (the tourist), the nucleus itself, and a marker that links the two.

In our study, we refer to Leiper's "marker" as "content," as this term be8er reflects its modern func9on. A marker would merely mark the loca9on of an a8rac9on, while content about the a8rac9on can serve many more func9ons. For example, online ra9ngs and reviews can reassure people of an a8rac9on's quality, while a magazine ar9cle can provide the context needed to understand it.

We further adapt Leiper's framework by not focusing exclusively on tourists. As Leiper himself noted (Leiper, 1979(Leiper, , 1997(Leiper, , 2008;;Page & Duignan, 2023), many a8rac9ons also depend on other customers, a point especially true in urban setngs (Leiper et al., 2008). Because our research examines how digitaliza9on impacts discovery across the en9re urban ecosystem, our study focuses on the discovery behaviors of people in general.

Our conceptual framework is illustrated in Figure 1. We define "urban discovery" as a process that begins with informa9on behavior about urban a8rac9ons not yet visited, extends into decision-making about visi9ng an urban a8rac9on, and ripples into the experience of visi9ng that urban a8rac9on. The discoverer in our framework is similar to what Leiper calls the person with touris9c needs (Leiper, 1990).

A key adapta9on of Leiper's work is our focus on collec9ve spaces rather than individual elements. We term the complete set of a city's a8rac9ons the "urban a8rac9on space." People frequently discover these a8rac9ons through the "urban a8rac9on content space"-the full body of digital and physical informa9on available about them. This divergence is necessary because, since Leiper's 9me, digital content marke9ng has dras9cally changed the way consumers discover urban a8rac9ons (Hollebeek & Macky, 2019). The emergence of pla3orms centralizing content about the urban a8rac9ons in an urban a8rac9on ecosystem opens the vast number of op9ons to customers. Therefore, instead of looking at individual markers and a8rac9ons, as in Leiper's original framework (Leiper, 1990(Leiper, , 1997)), we adapt his framework to focus on the spaces cons9tu9ng the urban ecosystem, namely the urban a8rac9on space and its content space. This perspec9ve gives us a broader view on informa9on and discovery behavior, uncovering discovery pa8erns that would otherwise remain hidden.

Like Richards (2002) points out, Leiper's framework holds untapped poten9al for studying and explaining discovery pa8erns through variables like familiarity, distance traveled, length of stay, and cultural capital. Our adapted model allows for different expressions of urban discovery, as shown in Figure 1. For instance, a person might learn of a new museum from a local broadcaster (a 'genera9ng marker' in Leiper's terms) and decide to visit. In contrast, another person might stumble upon a charming bar and impulsively decide to have a drink (prompted by a 'con9guous marker').
Figure 1 Conceptual framework of urban discovery within an urban a8rac9on ecosystem.
Note. Two examples of urban discovery in our conceptual framework. This framework is inspired on (Leiper, 1990).

As previously stated, to navigate the abundance of urban a8rac9ons, people increasingly rely on digital pla3orms (Gursoy et al., 2017;H. Kim et al., 2015;Xiang et al., 2015). However, we know li8le about how these pla3orms impact the process of discovering urban a8rac9ons, or what cons9tute good prac9ces for digital content marke9ng (Hollebeek & Macky, 2019). What is known is that the rise of these pla3orms presents both promises and perils for the urban a8rac9on ecosystem.

First is the paradox of online reviews. In theory, user-generated content should bridge the knowledge gap between consumers and providers, helping travelers make be8er decisions and avoid "tourist traps"-establishments that seem authen9c but offer poor quality (Polus et al., 2025). In prac9ce, however, research suggests that online reviews can strengthen the tourist trap phenomenon (Ganzaroli, De Noni, & Van Baalen, 2017). Furthermore, while reviews may sa9sfy a desire for certainty, they can also frustrate the search for authen9city, serendipity, and new experiences (Ritzer, 2019).

Second, the applica9on of recommender systems on these pla3orms helps consumers in discovering urban a8rac9ons they are likely to appreciate (Massimo & Ricci, 2022;Rabanser & Ricci, 2005). However, these recommender systems have also been associated with crea9ng overtourism (Merinov, 2024). For example, there is evidence for hotspots of restaurants in Belgian ci9es on TripAdvisor, suppor9ng the hypothesis that tourism a8racts tourism (Van Der Zee et al., 2020;Van der Zee & Bertocchi, 2018). Another danger of recommender systems in the urban a8rac9on ecosystem is the crea9on of urban filter bubbles, i.e., people are, because of algorithmic personaliza9on, only exposed to a specific part of the city that differs from what others, with a different user profile, are exposed to (Smets et al., 2019).

In summary, ra9ngs, reviews, and personalized recommenda9ons are associated with problems in the urban a8rac9on ecosystem such as overtourism, urban filter bubbles, and reinforcing tourist traps. Understanding how people discover urban a8rac9ons is a vital first step in addressing these issues.

To the best of our knowledge, no prior work has developed a theore9cal framework that explains how urban a8rac9ons are discovered. Most exis9ng studies focus on des9na9on decisionmaking (Moore et al., 2012;Smallman & Moore, 2010), which represents a different level of analysis with dis9nct characteris9cs. Des9na9on decisions typically involve higher costs and less immersion and are oeen made before the trip begins. In contrast, urban discovery unfolds within the city itself, allowing travelers to stumble upon a8rac9ons spontaneously and serendipitously. While des9na9onfocused theories offer valuable insights, they do not fully capture the dynamics of on-the-ground discovery. Other research concentrates on visitor a8rac9ons (Leask, 2016), using a narrower defini9on centered on man-made or natural sites designed to entertain or educate-such as monuments like the Sagrada Familia or landmarks like the Grand Canyon. Our approach adopts a broader perspec9ve, since we also focus on shops, ac9vi9es, bars, and restaurants. Neither lens fully captures the dynamics of urban discovery.

To address this gap, we conducted a grounded theory study involving 126 semi-structured interviews, an approach well-suited for developing nuanced, process-oriented theories in tourism and hospitality research (Decrop & Snelders, 2005;Moore et al., 2012;Woodside et al., 2004). Our analysis resulted in a typology of five dis9nct discovery modes: instrumental-ra9onal, go-with-theflow, social, flaneur, and habitual. In addi9on to describing each mode in depth, we link these discovery modes to their predictors, and to each other.

div.head: Related literature
div.p: In the context of grounded theory, sensi9zing concepts, i.e., concepts that guide the researcher in their study (Bowen, 2006), serve as a bridge between prior research and the new theore9cal framework being developed. These concepts help direct the ini9al stages of the grounded theory process by offering a lens through which relevant pa8erns and themes can be iden9fied (Bowen, 2006). In this sec9on, we intend to discuss the concepts and models that have sensi9zed our grounded theory analysis.

In this study, we conceptualize urban discovery as a process that begins with informa9on behavior about urban a8rac9ons not yet visited, that extends into decision-making on visi9ng an urban a8rac9on, and that ripples into the experience of urban a8rac9ons. Given this conceptualiza9on, we structure our review of the related literature into three key areas: (2.1.) decision-making models, which examines the cogni9ve and behavioral mechanisms involved in choosing to visit an a8rac9on; (2.2.) informa9on behavior, which explores how individuals seek and process informa9on about urban a8rac9ons; and (2.3.) factors that influence informa9on behavior and decision-making.

div.head: Decision-making in tourism and hospitality
div.p: Decision-making within the context of tourism and hospitality refers to the process by which individuals determine whether to visit a par9cular loca9on or engage with a specific a8rac9on.
Research on this subject has predominantly employed two analy9cal approaches: the varianceanalysis approach and the process approach (Smallman & Moore, 2010).

div.head: Variance analysis vs process approach
div.p: The variance-analysis approach has been the most commonly used framework in studies of tourism and hospitality decision-making (Cohen et al., 2014;Smallman & Moore, 2010). In this framework, the varia9on in outcomes-such as the decision to visit a par9cular des9na9on-is explained by a set of theore9cally significant inputs that are primarily chosen by researchers (Cohen et al., 2014;McCabe et al., 2016;Smallman & Moore, 2010). Methodologically, this approach is oeen paired with sta9s9cal techniques, including Structural Equa9on Modeling (SEM) and regression analyses, which serve to validate the rela9onships between the selected variables (Smallman & Moore, 2010). While the variance-analysis approach is effec9ve in iden9fying the key variables that influence decision-making, it has been cri9qued for providing only a superficial account of the processes involved and failing to elucidate how and why these decisions unfold (Decrop, 2014;Smallman & Moore, 2010).

In contrast, the process approach aims to capture the narra9ve of how a decision unfolds over 9me and in a specific context (Smallman & Moore, 2010), for example on-site tourist decisionmaking (Moore et al., 2012). It focuses on the socio-psychological processes involved in decisionmaking, including factors such as mo9va9on, mood, and individual decision-making style (Decrop & Snelders, 2005). Several prominent scholars have argued that research should complement the variance-analysis approach with studies adop9ng a process perspec9ve since this perspec9ve focuses on how individuals in prac9ce make decisions, which is a complicated process (Cohen et al., 2014;Decrop, 2014;Smallman & Moore, 2010). The process perspec9ve recognizes this complexity, and therefore should lead to more accurate theories of decision-making (Decrop, 2014;Smallman & Moore, 2010). Although this perspec9ve remains rare in the tourism and hospitality field, some previous studies have illustrated its poten9al for genera9ng insigh3ul and comprehensive theories of decision-making in specific contexts (Decrop & Snelders, 2005;Dunne et al., 2011;Moore et al., 2012).

Oeen, the process approach is combined with grounded theory, a methodological paradigm that allows researchers to explore nuanced and richly detailed theories of the phenomenon studied (Decrop & Snelders, 2005; Y. G. Kim et al., 2009;Moore et al., 2012;Woodside et al., 2004). Although its strength lies in untangling the complex interplay of factors that shape the decision-making process in a specific context, the process approach is frequently cri9cized for its limited generalizability to other contexts (Woodside et al., 2004). In this work, we adopt a process approach, as our goal is to explore how urban discovery unfolds across various contexts and among diverse individuals.

div.head: Theore1cal Paradigms
div.p: In addi9on to these methodological approaches, several theore9cal paradigms have been used to understand decision-making in hospitality and tourism. Here, we discuss three of the most influen9al theories.

Ra9onal choice theory assumes that individuals make decisions that maximize their u9lity (Decrop, 2014;Smallman & Moore, 2010). An example is the theory of planned behavior applied to the tourism and hospitality context (Sirakaya & Woodside, 2005), which posits that tourists' decisions are determined by their attudes toward a des9na9on, the influence of subjec9ve norms as reflected by their social network's percep9ons, and their perceived behavioral control, such as financial capacity to travel (Ulker-Demirel & Cieci, 2020;Yuzhanin & Fisher, 2016).

Choice set theories conceptualize decision-making as a funneling process whereby individuals move from a total set of op9ons to an awareness set, then a considera9on set, and ul9mately to a final choice (Sirakaya & Woodside, 2005). Both ra9onal choice and choice set theories assume a ra9onal actor model (Sirakaya & Woodside, 2005); however, cri9cs argue that these models describe how tourists should act according to micro-economic theory, which may not accurately reflect how tourists-in reality-act (Decrop, 2014). Consistent with their theore9cal underpinnings, these ra9onal actor models are most frequently examined using the variance-analysis approach (Smallman & Moore, 2010;Ulker-Demirel & Cieci, 2020).

Other paradigms challenge the assump9on of complete ra9onality. The concept of bounded ra9onality, for instance, acknowledges that prac9cal constraints-such as limited 9me and choice overload-oeen lead individuals to se8le for sa9sfactory rather than op9mal outcomes (Smallman & Moore, 2010). An example is the dual-system theory of tourism decision-making, in which variables like level of involvement and cogni9ve overload predict complex or heuris9c-based decision-making (McCabe et al., 2016).

Lastly, naturalis9c theories offer an alterna9ve perspec9ve by deconstruc9ng real-world decision-making through detailed analyses of discourse, narra9ve, or observa9onal data (Decrop, 2014;Smallman & Moore, 2010). Conversely to the theore9cal perspec9ves discussed above, naturalis9c theories are not grand, all encompassing, theories; they are delimited by a specific setng (Gore et al., 2006), for example, city break travel (Dunne et al., 2011) or on-site decisionmaking (Moore et al., 2012). These theories are oeen combined with a process-approach. We will adopt this theore9cal framework in order to get a rich understanding of the process of discovering urban a8rac9ons.

div.head: Informa;on behavior
div.p: Although informa9on behavior is oeen considered part of the decision-making process (Buhalis & Law, 2008;McCabe et al., 2016;Sirakaya & Woodside, 2005), this perspec9ve assumes a func9onal informa9on need-one that individuals seek to fulfill through informa9on behavior. However, informa9on behavior is not always goal-driven. It can also be mo9vated by the pleasure of, for example, dreaming about vaca9ons, without necessarily leading to a decision (Decrop & Snelders, 2005;Xiang & Fesenmaier, 2020). In many cases, travelers actually prefer serendipitous experiences, where they encounter informa9on about an interes9ng urban a8rac9on by accident, resul9ng in an impulsive decision to visit it (Huang et al., 2014). Thus, research on informa9on behavior offers a different lens on decision-making. In this sec9on, we discuss the informa9on behavior concepts and models that have shaped our grounded theory.

div.head: The discovery process
div.p: One of the most dominant perspec9ves on informa9on behavior is the linear perspec9ve which conceptualizes it as ini9ated by a func9onal informa9on need (i.e., focused on solving a specific task) that triggers a process meant to solve this func9onal informa9on need (Cohen et al., 2014;Xiang & Fesenmaier, 2020). The traveler des9na9on choice model by Woodside and Lysonski (1989) provides a good example of this perspec9ve. The model suggests that travelers follow a selec9on process that filters urban a8rac9ons from an awareness set to a set of preferences and finally towards a final choice. Seen from this perspec9ve, informa9on behavior is indeed part of the decision-making process.

The linear perspec9ve aligns with the sequen9al perspec9ve that is common in tourism and hospitality studies (Cohen et al., 2014;Xiang & Fesenmaier, 2020), and makes a dis9nc9on between the pre-purchase and ongoing informa9on search stage (Xiang & Fesenmaier, 2020). The prepurchase stage consists of planning the trip in advance while the ongoing informa9on search stage consists of informa9on behavior during the trip. A considerable amount of research emphasizes the pre-purchase stage, assuming that trips are me9culously planned (Cohen et al., 2014;Xiang & Fesenmaier, 2020). However, other research debunks this assump9on, showing that many decisions are made spontaneously during the trip (Hyde & Lawson, 2003;Zach & Gretzel, 2011), or based on habits (Bargeman & van der Poel, 2006). More recent studies have pivoted to acknowledge the significance of ongoing discovery during the trip itself, facilitated by the widespread adop9on of smartphones, the ubiquity of internet access, and the digital marketplace for apps (X. Liu et al., 2022;Wang et al., 2012;Xiang et al., 2015).

The 'travel network perspec9ve' (Xiang & Fesenmaier, 2020) also stresses the spontaneity of urban discovery. It views travel not just as a des9na9on but as a collec9on of experiences, ac9vi9es, and places, interwoven with one's daily life (Wang et al., 2012;Zach & Gretzel, 2011). An example is the hedonic vaca9oner, a type of vaca9oner in Decrop and Snelders' (2005) grounded typology about vaca9on decision-making who likes to dream and talk about their vaca9on plans.

In this context, the concept of 'informa9on encountering' becomes relevant, reflec9ng that people oeen acquire informa9on by encountering it rather than ac9vely seeking it (Erdelez & Makri, 2020). Here the rela9onship between informa9on behavior and decision making is turned upside down; decision-making is part of informa9on behavior. One browses content for fun, and this impulsively leads to a decision when something a8rac9ve is found (Huang et al., 2014). Research does suggest that everyday informa9on behavior oeen entails informa9on encountering and serendipity (Björneborn, 2017;Foster & Ford, 2003). Non-linear informa9on models put more emphasis on informa9on encountering. An example is the berrypicking model by Bates (1989) which proposes that users "pick" bits of informa9on from various content over 9me, adjus9ng their search path and behavior as their understanding and needs evolve.

Although researchers differ in their perspec9ves on how informa9on behavior develops, they generally agree on its inherent duality-dis9nguishing between goal-oriented, convergent ac9vi9es like searching for specific informa9on and exploratory, divergent ac9vi9es such as browsing (Björneborn, 2010a). Dörk and colleagues (2011) recognize this inherent duality of informa9on behavior but cri9cize the exclusive focus on func9onal informa9on behavior. To promote a more human-centered view of informa9on behavior they introduce the no9on of the informa9on flaneur (Dörk et al., 2011). This figure is mo9vated by curiosity and discovers informa9on in a playful yet cri9cal manner through horizontal explora9on-where they navigate the content landscape spontaneously mo9vated by their curiosity (Dörk et al., 2011). Upon encountering cap9va9ng content, they transi9on into ver9cal immersion, delving deeply into the subject, which sparks a sense of wonder (Dörk et al., 2011).

Informa9on behavior can indeed be dis9nguished based on the mo9va9on underlying it. This viewpoint is closely linked to the popular but contested concept of informa9on needs (Case & Given, 2016). Reflec9ng informa9on behavior literature in general, the tension between instrumental and playful mo9va9ons of informa9on behavior is also present in tourism and hospitality studies. For instance, Gursoy (2019a) interprets travel informa9on behavior as primarily driven by a desire to reduce uncertainty, because the intangible and oeen costly nature of some urban a8rac9ons. This view aligns with a 'func9onal need' for u9lity, certainty, and efficiency (Vogt & Fesenmaier, 1998).
However, Vogt and Fesenmaier (1998a) show that beyond func9onal informa9on needs, four other informa9on needs are relevant: hedonic, innova9on, aesthe9c and sign (i.e., social) informa9on needs.

2.1.4. The emergence of user generated content and review pla:orms Lastly, informa9on behavior can also be characterized by the content that communicates the informa9on (Xiang & Fesenmaier, 2020). The advent and widespread accessibility of the internet have not only increased the frequency and spontaneity of informa9on searches but have also enabled consumers to connect with one another and share their experiences through User Generated Content (UGC). This phenomenon has become a cornerstone for the success of social media and review pla3orms-such as TripAdvisor and Booking.com-which now serve as some of the most influen9al actors in the hospitality and tourism sector (Gössling et al., 2018;Horner & Swarbrooke, 2020).

Empirical studies indicate that peer-to-peer review pla3orms are among the most frequently consulted sources of informa9on by consumers (Dickinger, 2011;Gursoy et al., 2017). The aggregated ra9ngs provided by these pla3orms offer a straigh3orward metric for evalua9ng and selec9ng urban a8rac9ons (Pourfakhimi et al., 2020). Moreover, the posi9ve rela9onship between higher ra9ngs and increased sales (Ye et al., 2011) as well as larger booking transac9ons (Torres et al., 2015) suggests that consumers ac9vely incorporate these metrics into their decision-making processes.

The mechanisms underlying the influence of ra9ngs and reviews are complex (Pourfakhimi et al., 2020). Trust has been found to play a major role (Pop et al., 2022;Pourfakhimi et al., 2020;Serra Cantallops & Salvi, 2014). Trust in user generated content, in general, is shaped by mul9ple antecedents, including perceived credibility, informa9on quality, and website quality (Filieri et al., 2015). Focusing more specifically on reviews, research has demonstrated that while both posi9ve and nega9ve reviews increase consumer awareness of hotels, they par9cularly influence consumer attudes toward lesser-known hotels (Vermeulen & Seegers, 2009). Users interpret these reviews through heuris9c processes, relying on cues such as the perceived richness and factuality of the informa9on presented (Papathanassis & Knolle, 2011). Moreover, affec9ve factors play a cri9cal role in this interpre9ve process. For example, the degree of homophily-the extent to which a reviewer is perceived to resemble the reader-can enhance trust, which in turn posi9vely influences attudes toward and the inten9on to visit urban a8rac9ons (Ayeh et al., 2013). Addi9onally, a pronounced nega9vity bias oeen leads consumers to give dispropor9onate weight to nega9ve reviews, further impac9ng their decision-making (Papathanassis & Knolle, 2011;Pourfakhimi et al., 2020).

The prolifera9on of user-generated content (UGC) has expanded the availability of content on hospitality and tourism services to the point of crea9ng informa9on overload (Xiang & Fesenmaier, 2020). Consequently, the role of recommender systems and the perceived trustworthiness of UGC has become increasingly important in helping consumers navigate this abundance of content (Xiang & Fesenmaier, 2020). In our study, we aim to examine the extent to which individuals rely on UGC, and to explore how this reliance varies across different contexts.

div.head: Factors influencing decision-making and informa;on behavior
div.p: To fully understand how people discover urban a8rac9ons, we argue that we need to combine insights from informa9on behavior and decision-making theory. Furthermore, we claim that how travelers discover urban a8rac9ons is dependent on personal characteris9cs as well as social and affec9ve factors. Below, we provide an overview of the factors we consider in this study.

div.head: Personal factors
div.p: Familiarity: Returning tourists oeen seek more novel and unique experiences than less familiar travelers (Vogt & Fesenmaier, 1998). Tse and Cro8s (2005) also find that familiarity is linked to novelty seeking, expressed by experimenta9on with Hong Kong's diverse culinary tradi9ons.

Familiarity also affects informa9on behavior; experienced visitors tend to focus on prac9cal aspects of a visit, whereas novice travelers engage in a more extensive search for informa9on (Lehto et al., 2006).

Personality: Individuals with a higher need for achievement tend to prefer adventurous vaca9ons, while those with a stronger need for affilia9on are more inclined toward cultural experiences (Tran & Ralston, 2006). Also Lepp and Gibson (2008) find that personality traits influence travel style, repor9ng that sensa9on seekers prefer a more independent style of travel and pursue novel ac9vi9es.

div.head: Social factors
div.p: Travel party composi7on: Research indicates that the composi9on of a travel party significantly influences engagement with urban a8rac9ons. For instance, Thornton and colleagues (1997) observed that younger children notably influence the distribu9on of 9me across ac9vi9es, leading to more 9me spent in child-friendly loca9ons, such as beaches, and less on traveling or relaxing. Generally, as interpersonal constraints grow, so does the complexity of decision-making within travel groups (Kozak, 2010).

Cultural distance: While travelers are generally more likely to enjoy culturally similar services, they are more tolerant towards culturally different services because these are perceived as authen9c (Weiermair, 2000). However, cultural openness of visitors is an important precursor in the par9cipa9on in authen9c cultural ac9vi9es (Lin et al., 2021).

div.head: Contextual factors
div.p: Mo7va7on: When a city serves as a main des9na9on, visitors oeen seek relaxa9on, an escape from rou9ne, or opportuni9es to reconnect with family and friends (McKercher & Wong, 2004). These primary visitors are typically drawn to dining and shopping experiences, while secondary visitors show more interest in architecture, specific tourist sites, and local residents (McKercher & Wong, 2004). However, Huang and colleagues (2014) reveal no significant difference in independent travel styles between travelers at main des9na9ons and those on stopovers; both groups exhibit a preference for serendipitous travel.

div.head: Length of stay:
div.p: Research indicates that the length of stay significantly influences travel behavior. Moore et al. (2012) found that shorter stays are typically characterized by extensively planned i9neraries, whereas longer stays oeen involve more spontaneous, on-site decision making.
Addi9onally, Tse and Cro8s (2005) find that extended stays are associated with a greater propensity for novelty-seeking and a willingness to experiment with local culture.

div.head: Demographic factors
div.p: Age: Kim et al. (2015) highlight genera9onal differences in online informa9on behavior. They observe that older genera9ons prefer direct contact with suppliers of hospitality products while younger genera9ons prefer intermediaries such as TripAdvisor or Google. Furthermore, younger genera9ons also more frequently use social networking sites and UGC, while older genera9ons use online content that can be printed because they prefer tacit informa9on sources (H. Kim et al., 2015).

Gender: Men and women tend to play different roles in the decision-making process within tourism and hospitality. Women are less involved in financing trips yet play a greater role in planning them (Zalatan, 1998) and take the ini9a9ve in decision-making (Motar & Quinn, 2004). Research on informa9on behavior further reveals gender differences: women rely more oeen on word-of-mouth recommenda9ons during travel planning (Murphy et al., 2007), and rely more oeen on landmarks for naviga9on during wayfinding compared to men (Xia et al., 2008).

div.head: Affec1ve factors
div.p: Des7na7on image: A fun and friendly des9na9on image is an important pull factor for city break vaca9ons (Dunne et al., 2011). A des9na9on's image is shaped by both cogni9ve and affec9ve factors; however, affec9ve factors not only mediate the influence of cogni9ve factors but also serves as a stronger predictor of the overall image among tourists (Stylidis et al., 2017). This overall des9na9on image significantly influences key outcomes such as des9na9on sa9sfac9on, revisit inten9ons (Kani et al., 2017), and inten9on to recommend the des9na9on (Afshardoost & Eshaghi, 2020; Stylidis et al., 2017).

Emo7ons: emo9ons also play an important role in informa9on behavior and decision making. For example, emo9onal 9tles of UGC a8ract more a8en9on than informa9onal 9tles (Fu et al., 2024). Similarly, Liu et al's (2023) found that celebrity endorsements s9mulate inten9ons to visit a des9na9on only when they evoke emo9onal arousal. Furthermore, Scarpi et al. (2019) find that involvement with an event par9cularly increases place a8achment when the event feels authen9c.

The preceding review highlights the complex nature of decision-making in tourism but also reveals a fragmented body of literature. This fragmenta9on shows the need for a more integrated understanding, promp9ng our central research ques9on: How do people discover urban a8rac9ons in the contemporary digital age? The following sec9on details the methodology we employed to develop a holis9c typology that addresses this ques9on by integra9ng and extending the insights discussed above.

div.head: Methodology
div.p: To understand how users discover urban a8rac9ons, we conducted semi-structured interviews with 126 par9cipants in Belgium. Subsequently, we used the grounded theory framework to analyze this data (Strauss & Corbin, 2015). Below, we describe our Sampling approach (Sec9on 3.1), Interview protocol (Sec9on 3.2), and Grounded theory (Sec9on 3.3).

div.head: Sampling approach
div.p: Our study employed a two-phase sampling strategy, combining convenience and purposive sampling that resulted in a diverse sample of inhabitants of the Brussels and Flemish region of Belgium. In the first phase (October-December 2019), we relied on a convenience sampling approach, where 119 university students conducted each one interview, with a par9cipant outside their class, as part of a methodology course. Prior to conduc9ng the interviews, we introduced the students to the research context and research aim by guiding them through the topic guide provided by the researchers (see Appendix and Table 2). This ensured that the students understood the aim of the study, and that their interviews were comparable.

Upon analyzing the demographic composi9on of this ini9al sample, we iden9fied an age bias; we were missing the perspec9ve of par9cipants over 50. To address this, we (the researchers) conducted a second phase of purposive sampling (July-August 2024), purposively selec9ng seven par9cipants over 50. We applied two selec9on criteria during this phase: age, to ensure representa9on across different life stages, and gender, to ensure that each age category included at least one man and one woman. We do this because, as discussed in Sec9on 2.3.4, both demographic variables are related to tourism and hospitality behavior. This sampling approach deviates from the typical purposive sampling approach in grounded theory. However, due to the explora9ve nature of this study, it is especially important to have a diverse sample. As Table 1 illustrates, our sampling approach indeed resulted in a diverse sample. Note: all par9cipants are inhabitants of the Flemish or Brussels region of Belgium

div.head: Interview protocol
div.p: Par9cipants received an informed consent document outlining the study's purpose, data handling prac9ces, and privacy safeguards, following our ins9tute's template and data protec9on guidelines. Consent was obtained before recording began. Next, the interviewers started the recording and went through the topic guide ques9ons (see Appendix). We outline the general themes men9oned in the topic guide in Table 2. These topics relate to our central ques9on of how the rise of digital pla3orms, specifically, UGC review and ra9ng pla3orm have impacted the discovery of urban a8rac9ons. Interviews typically lasted between 40-70 minutes.

div.head: Grounded theory
div.p: We use grounded theory (Strauss & Corbin, 2015) to develop a theory of urban discovery.

This approach suits our focus on urban a8rac9ons, an understudied concept in need of fresh theore9cal development. Because grounded theory is induc9ve, it provides the originality necessary to explore this topic (Strauss & Corbin, 2015). Furthermore, it allows for a rich and nuanced descrip9on (Ma8eucci & Gnoth, 2017; Woodside et al., 2004). As explained in Sec9on 2.1.1, the process approach and grounded theory create an effec9ve combina9on (Decrop & Snelders, 2005;Moore et al., 2012;Woodside et al., 2004). Lastly, grounded theory seeks to explain phenomena, offering insight into why urban discovery unfolds as it does (Strauss & Corbin, 2015).

The grounded theory analysis started by immersing ourselves in the data by reading a random sample of interviews without coding (Mehmetoglu & Al9nay, 2006). Subsequently, we started open coding of interviews u9lizing MAXQDA soeware. This open coding facilitates the iden9fica9on and descrip9on of various concepts, as well as the me9culous documenta9on of analy9cal insights via memos. Such detailed documenta9on is essen9al as it aids in refining the codes-whether by discarding, modifying, or merging them as necessary-thus enabling the iden9fica9on of higher-level concepts and their respec9ve proper9es (Strauss & Corbin, 2015).

Subsequently, axial coding was employed to connect the different iden9fied concepts during open coding. This process was further enhanced by compara9ve analysis, which involves contras9ng incidents to discern similari9es and differences (Strauss & Corbin, 2015).

We also followed Strauss and Corbin's (2015) guidelines to determine when theore9cal satura9on had been achieved. Their main criterion is the theory's internal consistency and logical coherence. In our case, this means that the different discovery modes must be clearly dis9nguished, their elements thoroughly conceptualized, and their processual development free of gaps. Based on our theore9cal framework, summarized in Table 3, we believe this criterion has been met.
We further tested theore9cal satura9on during the final five interviews, which were conducted by the lead author. At the end of each interview, we presented our theore9cal model (see

Table 3) and asked par9cipants if it resonated with their experiences. Par9cipants oeen recognized themselves in the different discovery modes and recalled how they had discovered urban a8rac9ons through various discovery modes.

div.head: Discovery modes
div.p: Our grounded theory analysis revealed five dis9nct discovery modes: instrumental-ra9onal, go-with-the-flow, social, flaneur, and habitual. Sec9on 4.1 offers a detailed descrip9on of each mode, which are summarized in Table 3.
It is important to note that our theore9cal framework does not prescribe a value hierarchy;

the value and adop9on of the five discovery modes are highly situa9onal, and an individual may adopt different modes depending on the context. To build on our ini9al descrip9ons, we therefore analyze the factors influencing the adop9on of a par9cular discovery mode (Sec9on 4.2) and then explore the rela9onships between the discovery modes themselves (Sec9on 4.3).

div.head: Instrumental-ra5onal
div.p: Go-with-the-flow Social Flaneur Habitual Key values Price-quality ra.o, certainty, predictability Serendipity, ease, spontaneity Social contact Resonance, dis.nc.on, authen.city Tradi.ons, feeling at ease, predictability, certainty

div.head: Mo5va5on of discovery process
div.p: Func In instrumental-ra9onal discovery mode, individuals primarily value predictability and price-quality in their search for urban a8rac9ons. These discoverers try to ensure their limited 9me and money is invested wisely in worthwhile hospitality experiences, aiming to avoid disappointment.

The explora9on process in this mode is mo9vated by a 'func9onal informa9on need' (Vogt & Fesenmaier, 1998). Typical situa9ons are for example finding a restaurant for a roman9c date or planning an important event as Par9cipant 21 illustrates "If I want to go somewhere special to eat with someone, say for a birthday or for Christmas, I do want it to stand out, that it's special. That's why I will look for a place with good reviews."

Func9onal informa9on needs are intertwined with an instrumental view on informa9on and discovery. Instrumental-ra9onal discoverers are solely focused on iden9fying the best places to visit and hence driven by extrinsic mo9va9on. Their primary concern is that the discovery process be efficient and effec9ve. For example, when asked which kind of recommenda9on is preferred, by a friend or by an algorithm, Par9cipant 50 answers pragma9cally: "I think the algorithm, because it knows more," which is in stark contrast to the intrinsically mo9vated informa9on behavior in playful discovery modes, as is discussed later.

This instrumental attude manifests in their discovery prac9ces. They primarily leverage review pla3orms and search engines as their interface to discover the city. In par9cular ra9ngs, reviews, and filters are deemed indispensable as they allow a thorough comparison of the urban a8rac9on space through the urban a8rac9on content space. Instrumental-ra9onal discoverers use filters to dis9l a relevant set of urban a8rac9ons and subsequently thoroughly compare them before deciding on the highest-rated and best-reviewed op9ons. Par9cipant 6 provides an apt example of this explora9on and immersion process:

div.head: Playful discovery modes
div.p: We use the label playful discovery modes to refer to the go-with-the-flow, social, and flaneur discovery modes, since all these modes describe a discovery process driven by intrinsic mo9va9on.

In these modes enjoying urban discovery is as important as the quality of the outcome. The inherent pleasure associated with the discovery process oeen transforms it into a story worth sharing, as Discoverers who adopt a go-with-the-flow mode are mo9vated by inspira9onal informa9on needs. Unlike the me9culous scou9ng of flaneurs or the systema9c searching of instrumental-ra9onal discoverers, they engage with their environment spontaneously and impulsively.

Consequently, their explora9on unfolds haphazardly as they inspect their immediate surroundings, immersing themselves instantly when something intriguing is encountered. This all expresses itself in their discovery prac9ces. They prefer to lead their own explora9on rather than depending on recommenda9ons, ra9ngs, or reviews. Their laid-back approach has them meandering through the city-typically by foot-open to the allure of aesthe9c details that may draw them impulsively into a restaurant, even if it deviates from their original i9nerary.

Interes9ngly, the rise of online reserva9ons means that ac9vi9es oeen require advanced planning. Weijts (2023) captures this loss of spontaneity well, cri9cizing the growing challenge of, for example, dining in a good restaurant without prior reserva9ons. This loss clearly reverberates in our interviews. For example, Par9cipant 120 men9ons: "It is annoying for example when I want to do a trip, I have to make reserva9ons for everything well in advance … I do miss some flexibility on vaca9on." This clashes with the go-with-the-flow ethos, which thrives on unscripted discovery.

div.head: Social discovery mode
div.p: Social interac9ons lie at the heart of the social discovery mode. Social discoverers leverage their social network as an interface to discover the city. However, the value placed on social interac9ons transcends mere informa9on gathering; it is a conduit for nurturing rela9onships, offering a base for future conversa9ons as Par9cipant 30 encapsulates when explaining why he prefers recommenda9ons by friends over digital recommenda9ons: "because I want to know more about this friend of course. What does he like, then we can chat about that, do I like this?"

Social discoverers engage with urban a8rac9ons through a con9nuous stream of social interac9ons, ranging from direct encounters-such as conversa9ons with colleagues-to more indirect touchpoints, like scrolling through social media feeds. What dis9nguishes these individuals is their drive to be both inspired and informed by their social network. They are mo9vated by a social informa9on need, or what Vogt and Fesenmaier (1998) refer to as a "sign need"-the reliance on the opinions and experiences of their social contacts regarding urban a8rac9ons.

Beside exploring the urban a8rac9on space through their social network, they also immerse themselves in specific urban a8rac9ons by consul9ng their social network. Par9cipant 27 describes this reliance on her social network for discovering and deciding what is worthwhile to visit: "In both cases, both domes9c and foreign, I am more likely to rely on people I know. For example, before the trip to Norway, I talked about it with a friend who had taken a very long trip there, and with whom I looked at her i9neraries, the places they had been and even went through photo albums. I listened to what they recommended; people rather than digital recommenda9ons."
Social discoverers rely on social informa9on sources because they trust them over other sources. They believe their network understands their preferences be8er than any algorithm could.

The in9mate understanding of their preferences by their social network is seen as the expression of true friendship. Addi9onally, feelings of affec9on towards individuals who make recommenda9ons also cons9tutes an important explana9on in the preference for social informa9on sources. When asked which kind of recommenda9ons are preferred-by a friend or an algorithm-Par9cipant 97's response is telling: "A friend because they love you, it's that simple. That goes far beyond pleasing me, it is about enriching each other and sharing."

On the other hand, we also observe that digitaliza9on and the internet might facilitate social connec9on. While not the UGC pla3orms that were the focus of our interview topics, other digital pla3orms, such as social media, can foster the social connec9ons valued by social discoverers.

Indeed, our smartphones give us easy access to interact with our social networks at all 9mes. A different example of how technology can support social discoverers is the app "ManyGuide", men9oned by Par9cipant 50. These tools connect visitors of Brussels and Amsterdam with locals providing "a combina9on of what technology is good at and what people are be8er at."

div.head: Flaneur mode
div.p: At the heart of the urban flaneur is a roman9c attude towards the city. This roman9c attude drives the urban flaneur to discover their big love, expressing itself in unbridled curiosity. Their quest is to find resonance within the city-a concept championed by Rosa (2019) to describe a touching connec9on with the world.

Urban a8rac9ons that are perceived as authen9c typically resonate with the flaneur. This is illustrated by Par9cipant 37's preference for Brussels over Geneva: "The shops are really nice. It is much be8er than Geneva. Geneva, it's mostly brands and it's quite expensive. And the shops are not that interes9ng in Geneva. They spark my interest in Brussels actually. You have a lot of small shops, bou9ques, much smaller, with a soul," illustra9ng the urban flaneur's a8rac9on to places that resonate through character and vibe.
The flaneur is par9cularly enthusias9c to discover the city's hidden gems, like Par9cipant 12:

"I look for hidden spots where most tourists don't come, but where for example locals or young people oPen write about on their blog: 'ah I discovered that park over there,' and actually, in that way I find cool, ar9s9c, different things than in the average guidebooks." As illustrated above, they aspire to dis9nguish themselves from regular tourists by leveraging informa9on sources beyond what regular tourists use. As outlined in Bourdieu's Dis9nc9on (1984), the pursuit of dis9nc9on-the desire to differen9ate oneself from others-is deeply embedded in social prac9ces and iden99es.

Bourdieu argues that individuals leverage various forms of capital, such as social, economic, and cultural capital, to establish and maintain their dis9nc9veness. For example, someone with extensive social capital might u9lize their connec9ons to access exclusive venues, setng themselves apart from those with a less pres9gious social network. Similarly, individuals with significant economic resources purchase premium hospitality services to assert their dis9nc9on over those with more modest financial backgrounds (Ahmad, 2014;T. Liu & Li, 2020). Being a flaneur is also part of one's iden9ty and follows a similar pursuit of dis9nc9on but by harnessing their cultural capitalknowledge and familiarity with the city and its background-to differen9ate themselves explicitly from tourists or others unfamiliar with the city's hidden charms, as is also supported by the findings in (Ahmad, 2014).

Furthermore, flaneurs are characterized by their recep9vity to and respect for their surroundings. Their recep9vity is expressed by prac9ces that enable them to fully absorb their environment, like Par9cipant 97: "Yes, my eyes. I wander of course. I explore, hence the wandering. I try out a lot." Dörk and colleagues' (2011) describe the urban flaneur as someone who wanders without a specific goal, with the primary purpose of immersing themselves in the vibrancy of city life.

Therefore, they are par9cularly fond of content which s9mulates the senses and triggers telepresence (Steuer, 1995), aligning with their desire for resonance and 'aesthe9c informa9on need' (Vogt & Fesenmaier, 1998).

Their respect is a logical consequence of their roman9c rela9onship with the city. This respect is expressed by Par9cipant 123: "We try to learn some basics of the language. To travel with respect for the city. With respect for the climate and environment. I also consciously avoid visi9ng interna9onal chains that are known for tax fraud … We want to contribute to the local economy."

The flaneur explores and immerses themself in the city by using a rich plethora of informa9on prac9ces such as talking to locals or experts about the city, reading books about the city, and wandering through the city. Similarly to instrumental-ra9onal discovery mode, this might result in rigorously planning a trip. However, in this case the planning process is not instrumental for guaranteeing a worthwhile trip, but inherently pleasant. Indeed, it is a pathway to get hyped about a trip as Par9cipant 121 states: "Witness our roadbook. But for me, that contributes to the success of the vaca9on. You also have the pleasure of planning the trip, of ge[ng excited in an9cipa9on of it."
Lastly, their discovery prac9ces are characterized by a desire for agency because they desire to forge a unique bond with the city.

Their roman9c rela9onship with the city and extensive informa9on behavior results in affec9ve decision-making. They follow their refined and informed taste as a guide through the city, deciding what to visit depending on how strongly it resonates: "It does happen on vaca9on that we spontaneously enter a store, preferably not a touris9c one, but for example, a glassblower. Sure, it's pricey, but we will take a look because the ar9stry is excep9onal."

At the same 9me, they are cri9cal observers of the city. Because of their in9mate rela9onship with the city, they have strong opinions about its evolu9on. Par9cipant 97, for example, cri9cizes popularity bias in recommender systems: "that aggressive dynamic of apps, of something where a lot of people go, ... You only have a subgroup that gives ra9ngs, that system is not right at all. It's conceptually flawed, you certainly no9ce that with restaurants and tourists, they visit en masse the same places." The flaneur, in pursuit of authen9city and resonance, oeen feels alienated in these overly touris9c loca9ons.

div.head: Habitual discovery mode
div.p: Habitual discovery mode is characterized by a preference for the familiar, offering ease, predictability, and certainty. Although discovery typically implies venturing into the unknown, these travelers deliberately seek out familiar urban a8rac9ons-even within unfamiliar setngs. By anchoring their experiences with recognizable elements, such as global franchises, they balance the thrill of new experiences with the comfort of the familiar.

Habitual discovery mode resembles instrumental-ra9onal discovery mode in its desire for predictability and certainty. Yet, habitual discoverers do not care to find the best urban a8rac9on for their money; they desire to feel at ease. In this sense, they are similar to go-with-the-flow mode.

However, while people in go-with-the-flow mode are open and recep9ve for new experiences, people in habitual discovery mode are looking for anchors of familiarity. Par9cipant 97 aptly expresses this desire for familiarity: "Some9mes you seek the familiar, but that depends very much on your emo9onal state, some9mes you just want the familiar because you want to 'come home'."

These familiar places engender one's comfort zone, which is created through rituals, i.e., repeated scripts of ac9ons in a certain situa9on. An example of a ritual is visi9ng the Hard Rock Café on each city trip. Indeed, the Hard Rock Café company smartly taps into this discovery mode. In his book Interac9on ritual chains, Collins (2004) lays out a theory on how rituals can lead to strong emo9onal and moral associa9ons to symbols through the effervescence created during these rituals.

This theory helps us understand why in habitual mode, we can have such desire to visit the same places and why this has posi9ve psychological effects (Singh et al., 2020). Research shows that rituals can increase enjoyment of consump9on (Vohs et al., 2013).

div.head: Linking the discovery modes to their determinants and moderators
div.p: In Sec9on 4.1., we thoroughly described the five discovery modes. In this sec9on, we delve deeper into how personal, social, contextual, demographic, and affec9ve factors guide individuals toward one mode or another, as illustrated in Figure 2.

Our interviews suggest that personality, par9cularly openness to experience and need for cogni9ve closure, are important predictors. People high in openness to experience-characterized by curiosity, sensi9vity to aesthe9cs, and a8en9veness to internal feelings (Costa Jr & McCrae, 2000;McCrae & Costa, 1997)-are more likely to discover in go-with-the-flow or flaneur mode. Conversely, those lower in openness typically gravitate toward habitual discovery.
In contrast, a pronounced need for cogni9ve closure-discomfort with ambiguity and preference for clear outcomes (Roets & Van Hiel, 2011)-discourages go-with-the-flow discovery.

Par9cipant 10 illustrates how this need instead favors instrumental-ra9onal discovery: "I am the kind of person who likes to have control over situa9ons, so I want an ac9vity to be planned quite a while in advance. According to me, that ensures that I never or at least rarely experience any surprises." The desire for spontaneity, characteris9c in go-with-the-flow mode, contrasts sharply with the need for cogni9ve closure. In heterogeneous travel par7es, people are also more likely to desire cogni9ve closure since there are varied interests and physical constraints which make it more difficult to spontaneously encounter something sa9sfying, hence favoring instrumental-ra9onal discovery. For example, Par9cipant 120 shares that, when she is on vaca9on with her mother, she looks on the internet for a place that fits the following criteria: "something that is accessible for a person with mobility problems, with a parking place nearby, and with a nice view so it feels different than si[ng in her own house." A heterogeneous travel party also favors habitual discovery mode; par9cularly kids enjoy the familiarity of interna9onal fast-food chains, and it oeen becomes a tradi9on to visit these places during vaca9ons. On the other hand, homogeneous travel par7es are more likely to discover in a spontaneous way and make affec9ve decisions since their taste and intui9on guiding them through the city is similar. For example, Par9cipant 121 explains how she discovers places more spontaneously with her younger daughter compared with her older daughter because: "We are very similar. We can discover and decide where to go based on intui9on."

Also charm is an important trigger for affec9ve decision-making, s9mula9ng go-with-theflow and flaneur discovery. As Par9cipant 27 describes: "Recently, we were in Paris and wanted to go to Musée Bourdelle, to a fashion exposi9on. But on our way, we like to enjoy Paris, discover some new places; and when we stumbled upon a charming café, we said: 'Oh, this looks lovely; let's stop for a coffee!'" In flaneur mode, charm is oeen 9ed to authen9city, shaped by one's cultural understanding of the city. In contrast, those in go-with-the-flow mode follow personal taste without considering authen9city, making them more prone to tourist traps.

Regarding social discovery mode, here mainly taste of the other person giving the recommenda9on is important. Some people's recommenda9ons are trusted more than others. While certain recommenda9ons are blindly followed, others are verified through sources like TripAdvisor, resul9ng in an instrumental-ra9onal way of discovering. As Par9cipant 37 explains: "I think you need to know the people. Recently, we have been recommended a restaurant by our neighbors, and it was not great for us… If some of my friends recommend me a place, I will go; without checking the internet, because I know their taste and I know it will get along with mine. For other people, it's a bit difficult; I will always crosscheck on the internet, like TripAdvisor."
Lastly, we note that age is also related with the adopted discovery mode. Younger individuals tend to favor go-with-the-flow and instrumental-ra9onal discovery for their ease and efficiency.
Older individuals, with more accumulated knowledge, life experience, and available 9me, are more likely to explore in flaneur mode.

div.head: Linking the discovery modes to each other
div.p: Not all discovery modes are equally compa9ble. While playful modes can blend to create mixed types, the instrumental-ra9onal and habitual modes are incompa9ble with others. The following sec9on explores these compa9bili9es in detail.

div.head: Compa1ble modes
div.p: The playful discovery modes are mutually compa9ble, each characterized by an inherently enjoyable process of explora9on. Although they do not always occur simultaneously-otherwise, they would not be conceptualized as dis9nct modes-they some9mes overlap. Indeed, our par9cipants gave some anecdotes that can be both characterized as flaneur and social discovery mode. Flaneurs enjoy gathering diverse content about the city and par9cularly value sugges9ons from locals since they oeen result in authen9c experiences. Par9cipant 126 recalls an anecdote illustra9ng the discovery of a viewpoint that embodies both discovery modes:
"We were in Josselin, si[ng in our car, ready to leave for our next accommoda9on. First, we stopped at a local bakery. As we cha8ed with the baker, he asked, 'Have you been up the basilica tower?'

'No, we walked all over the city and saw everything-but go up the tower-no, that we didn't do yet. You can't do it all, can you?' 'But you can't leave without going up! You'll thank me later-the view is magnificent.'' So we decided to go, messaging our next host that we'd be late. And the baker was rightthe view was incredible. We took photos, saw the city and castle from above, and aPerward, we returned to the bakery to tell him, 'You were right. It was absolutely worth it.'" Our par9cipants also shared discoveries that could be characterized by both social and gowith-the-flow mode. Social discovery mode emphasizes the role of social interac9ons, while go-withthe-flow mode highlights the ease and tranquility of unplanned explora9on. Par9cipant 120 recalled serendipitously encountering friends she had not seen in years and how their sugges9ons inspired her plans during the trip: "We encountered friends that we hadn't seen for at least fiPeen years. They gave us a couple of 9ps for things to do with the kids. In that way, we have discovered many things to do. I like that, to discover a8rac9ons at the des9na9on itself."

Lastly, also go-with-the-flow and flaneur mode some9mes occur together. While flaneur mode is characterized by thorough informa9on behavior, it also involves exploring the city on foot-a behavior that naturally leads to the spontaneous encounters characteris9c of go-with-the-flow mode. Par9cipant 37 gives an example of a combina9on of both: "At the beginning I used digital sources for everything. I went on internet and then you end up at websites about Brussels, like the official one, but also other websites and blogs. You find what to do in the city, also through books about the city. And then you walk and discover; I discovered actually most of the shops by walking around."

div.head: Incompa1ble modes
div.p: While playful discovery modes seamlessly blend into one another, they remain dis9nct from instrumental-ra9onal and habitual discovery modes. These modes are shaped by fundamentally opposing values, attudes, and informa9on prac9ces.

For example, social and instrumental-ra7onal discovery mode contrast sharply in informa9on behavior. Social discoverers rely on personal networks for recommenda9ons, while instrumental-ra9onal discoverers place greater trust in online ra9ngs and reviews, as illustrated by Conversely, social discoverers priori9ze human connec9on and personal interac9on in their discovery process, as illustrated by Par9cipant 18: "I trust my friends' recommenda9ons moresomeone who has actually been there makes it feel more personal. Just because the internet says something is good doesn't mean you should go-it lacks the human touch."

Flaneur and instrumental-ra7onal mode are also incompa9ble. While instrumental-ra9onal discoverers seek objec9ve metrics to ensure they receive value for money, flaneurs pursue a more subjec9ve and roman9c rela9onship with the city. They seek out hidden gems known only to true connoisseurs. As Par9cipant 21 puts it: "I don't brainlessly follow reviews or the whole crowd. When everybody says that a restaurant is really good, everybody will go eat there, and this is not what I want. I want to find something special."

Although both Instrumental-ra7onal and go-with-the-flow are more common among younger travelers, they also are incompa9ble. Go-with-the-flow discoverers embrace spontaneity and serendipitous encounters, whereas instrumental-ra9onal discoverers seek certainty and predictability. Par9cipant 24 illustrates this contrast: "If a recommenda9on has a very good ra9ng, by a lot of people, we will definitely follow it," When asked whether they would s9ck to their plan-even if they encountered something par9cularly a8rac9ve, they firmly replied: "Yes, we would, because looks can be deceiving."

Habitual discovery mode is incompa7ble with all other discovery modes. It is seldomly one's first choice like Par9cipant 123 explains: "If we really have no clue, then we just go to something Italian" but a bit later in the interview, she adds: "Italian food for us, it is not our first choice. Definitely not. We eat Italian if we really don't know where to go; if we are 9red; if we have to catch a train." This mode oeen leads travelers back to their comfort zones, par9cularly aeer an unexpected setback. Par9cipant 126 recounts such an experience: "My daughter's train had stood s9ll in a field for hours. We had planned to eat Indian, because a colleague who had lived in Paris had recommended a place. But when she arrived, it was already super late, so we decided to go for a hamburger."

div.head: Discussion
div.p: 5.1. Theore;cal contribu;on

div.head: Ontological contribu1on
div.p: This study shows that Leiper's (1990) framework, even 35 years aeer its publica9on, remains a produc9ve tool for genera9ng new insights. Inspired by his work, we developed a conceptual framework for urban discovery (see Figure 1), adap9ng his original theory in two key ways. First, we shieed the focus from tradi9onal tourist sites to all a8rac9ons. Second, we zoomed out from

individual "markers" to analyze a collec9ve "urban a8rac9on content space." These adapta9ons were necessary to suit the modern context, where digital pla3orms expose people to en9re ecosystems of a8rac9ons and where "pull" marke9ng strategies are as important as tradi9onal "push" methods (Godin, 1999;Hollebeek & Macky, 2019).

To answer our research ques9on-How do people discover urban a8rac9ons today?-we conceptualized urban discovery as a dynamic process, responding to calls for a process-oriented ontology in tourism research (Decrop, 2014;Smallman & Moore, 2010). This ontology allowed us to develop a rich and nuanced typology of urban discovery modes, and to associate these different discovery modes to personal, social, contextual, demographic, and affec9ve factors (Decrop, 2014;Sirakaya & Woodside, 2005).

Finally, our conceptual framework helps interpret pressing challenges in the urban a8rac9on ecosystem. For instance, cri9cal consumer culture (Gössling et al., 2018) can be understood as the influence of ra9ngs and reviews in the urban a8rac9on content space on urban discovery and consequently on the success of urban a8rac9ons. Urban filter bubbles-i.e., people might only see a par9cular part of the city, which is different from what other people are exposed to, because of algorithmic personaliza9on (Smets et al., 2019)-can be understood as a consequence of too much personaliza9on in the urban a8rac9on content space. And lastly, tourist traps (Ganzaroli, De Noni, & van Baalen, 2017) can be understood as a lack of informa9on about the authen9city and quality of urban a8rac9ons during urban discovery. By contextualizing these challenges within our framework, we offer fresh theore9cal and prac9cal perspec9ves to address them.

div.head: The five discovery modes
div.p: Our conceptual framework, inspired by Leiper's tourist a8rac9ons systems, tourist a8rac9on system, defines the universe in which urban discovery occurs. Our typology of discovery modes, in turn, adds flesh to the bone by describing the dis9nct pa8erns and forms urban discovery can take.

Metaphorically speaking, our conceptual framework provides the hardware on which our five discovery modes, the soeware, runs. By developing this typology, our study taps into the poten9al that Richards (2002) iden9fied in Leiper's work to explain how people interact with informa9on in different contexts.

We iden9fied five dis9nct discovery modes: instrumental-ra9onal, go-with-the-flow, social, flaneur, and habitual. Beyond richly describing these modes, we examined the personal, social, contextual, demographic, and affec9ve factors that influence their likelihood. We also analyzed their rela9onships, demonstra9ng that the playful discovery modes-go-with-the-flow, social, and flaneur-are compa9ble because they all three capture an inherently enjoyable discovery process, leading to mixed modes of discovery. In contrast, the remaining modes are incompa9ble, shaped by opposing values, attudes, and mo9va9ons-which cannot co-occur. In the next paragraphs, we connect the five discovery modes to exis9ng literature, illustra9ng how our typology integrates and synthesizes a lot of previously more fragmented research.

Instrumental-ra7onal discovery aligns with the dominant perspec9ve of consumer behavior in the field of tourism and hospitality (Cohen et al., 2014;Xiang & Fesenmaier, 2020). It can be described by linear informa9on behavior models (Woodside & Lysonski, 1989;Xiang & Fesenmaier, 2020) driven by func9onal informa9on needs, where individuals seek goal-directed solu9ons (Björneborn, 2010b;Vogt & Fesenmaier, 1998). Decision-making in this mode follows ra9onal choice and choice-set theory (Sirakaya & Woodside, 2005) and review pla3orms play a crucial role in this process (Dickinger, 2011;Gursoy, 2019;Pourfakhimi et al., 2020). This mode aligns closely with Decrop and Snelders' (2005) concept of the "ra9onal vaca9oner," who me9culously plans and researches their trip.

Go-with-the-flow discovery, in contrast, aligns with non-linear models of informa9on behavior, par9cularly the no9on of informa9on encountering (Erdelez & Makri, 2020). Unlike instrumental-ra9onal discoverers, who rely on comparisons of ra9ngs on pla3orms, these travelers engage directly with their surroundings, embracing serendipity over systema9zed evalua9on (Huang et al., 2014). Decisions are made on the spot, guided less by calculated trade-offs and more by immediate impressions, intui9on, and charm. When something in the environment sparks a strong emo9onal response-such as the appeal of a cozy café or a picturesque alley-it can prompt a spontaneous decision to visit, bypassing delibera9on en9rely (Dai et al., 2022). This reflects the affect heuris9c, in which choices are driven by posi9ve or nega9ve feelings rather than by analy9cal reasoning (Slovic et al., 2006). This discovery mode fits Hyde's (2008) descrip9on of the independent traveler, who feels the need to discover the unplanned and takes advantage of serendipitous opportuni9es. Smartphones and review pla3orms both support and hinder this discovery style.

While they allow travelers to quickly look up places that sa9sfy impromptu desires (X. Liu et al., 2022;Wang et al., 2012;Xiang et al., 2015), the widespread prac9ce of advance reserva9ons can frustrate flexibility, oeen leaving no availability for last-minute discoveries.

Social discovery's main contribu9on to the literature is that habitual word-of-mouth remains highly influen9al in discovering urban a8rac9ons (Gildin, 2022). Despite the growing reliance on digital pla3orms, personal recommenda9ons from friends, family, and acquaintances con9nue to shape urban explora9on. It also illustrates that, beyond peer-review pla3orms, social media plays a crucial role in urban discovery, offering a dynamic and visually driven way for travelers to explore urban a8rac9ons in a social way. Therefore, "Instagrammability" of urban a8rac9ons is important for a8rac9ng social discoverers browsing their social media (Yu et al., 2020;Yu & Sun, 2019). Social media influencers also play an important role in this process, as their recommenda9ons oeen guide travel decisions (Pop et al., 2022;Xu et al., 2021). Regarding decision-making, we find evidence for the homophily effect described by Ayeh et al. (2013), not only on digital pla3orms but also in the context of recommenda9ons received through one's social network more broadly. Furthermore, affec9on towards the person recommending something is also an important factor influencing the decision to follow recommenda9ons, implying that especially the engagement of the fanbase of social influencers is important for their "influence."

Flaneur mode involves broad informa9on behavior, mirroring Xiang and Fesenmaier's (2020) travel network perspec9ve, which views tourism as an extension of daily life. In this sense, our findings resemble Decrop and Snelders (2005) depic9on of the hedonic vaca9oner, who enjoys dreaming, thinking, and talking about their journey. Our findings also support Dörk et al.'s (2011) no9on of the "informa9on flaneur," whose pursuit of knowledge is guided by aesthe9c and hedonic informa9on needs (Vogt & Fesenmaier, 1998), rather than purely func9onal ones. Regarding informa9on sources, the flaneur focuses on alterna9ve channels such as travel blogs, habitual guidebooks, and direct interac9on with locals, rather than the peer-review pla3orms common in other modes. In terms of decision-making, flaneurs are also guided by the affect heuris9c (Slovic et al., 2006), like people in go-with-the-flow mode, but the affec9ve evalua9on is here based on the criterium of authen9city. This mode of visi9ng urban a8rac9ons is intertwined with the discoverers iden9ty which is highlighted by dis9nguishing oneself by leveraging one's knowledge of the city (Bourdieu, 1984;Yolal, 2016).

Lastly, habitual discovery aligns strongly with Decrop and Snelders' (2005) "habitual vaca9oner," who revisits the same places to feel at home. Reflec9ng 2004) theory of interac9on ritual chains, these habitual prac9ces create strong emo9onal and moral associa9ons with par9cular symbols due to the effervescence experienced during the ritual itself. This theore9cal insight helps explain why travelers in habitual mode repeatedly revisit familiar places, deriving posi9ve psychological benefits from such rituals (Singh et al., 2020). Indeed, exis9ng research supports the idea that rituals enhance the enjoyment derived from consump9on (Vohs et al., 2013). Recognizing these ritualis9c decisionmaking processes has clear implica9ons for tourism and hospitality management, sugges9ng that fostering symbolic and ritualis9c associa9ons with hospitality brands can effec9vely increase customer loyalty and overall sa9sfac9on.

The ini9al goal of this exploratory interview study was to understand the impact of peerreview pla3orms and UGC on urban discovery. While we observed that they can play an important role, we find that travelers s9ll turn to a wide range of content and prac9ces beyond comparing online reviews. UGC pla3orms most strongly influence instrumental-ra9onal discoverers who want to be sure they get the best value for their money and 9me. However, this study also emphasizes the importance of alterna9ve informa9on sources such as word-of-mouth or simply wandering the city.

In contrast, those in go-with-the-flow mode seek serendipity and flexibility, while people in flaneur mode are looking for enchantment, authen9city, and taste broadening. Future research can inves9gate how to capture the a8en9on of people in these la8er modes. For example, through alterna9ve features and affordances, such as maintaining mystery through non-standardized ra9ngs
or removing the op9on to make reserva9ons.

div.head: Implica7ons for the urban a=rac7on ecosystem
div.p: These five discovery modes have important implica9ons for contemporary challenges within the urban a8rac9on ecosystem. For instance, the self-propelling effect of UGC observed by Van Der Zee and colleagues (2018, 2020) appears to stem primarily from instrumental-ra9onal discovery.
Travelers in this mode are most likely to select a8rac9ons with the largest number of highly rated reviews, thus reinforcing a cycle in which popular a8rac9ons a8ract s9ll more a8en9on.

However, flaneur and go-with-the-flow mode hold poten9al to break these hotspot-effects by their desire for serendipity and discovering hidden gems. Flaneurs ac9vely seek out less-traveled routes and unique experiences. They priori9ze exploring local culture and contribute posi9vely to the local economy. Based on our research findings, we argue that such attudes foster sustainable interac9ons with urban environments, encouraging respect for local culture and heritage, suppor9ng
local businesses, and mi9ga9ng the ecological impacts associated with travel.

People discovering in go-with-the-flow mode do not necessarily seek these less-traveled routes but like to casually wander through ci9es, spontaneously deciding where to go based on immediate surroundings and personal impulses. Unlike flaneurs, who possess cultural capital that allows them to appreciate historically or culturally rich but visually less appealing areas, go-with-theflow travelers might lack such background knowledge. Consequently, they might gravitate toward easily accessible, a8rac9ve, and oeen tourist-heavy areas. However, as noted previously, these two playful modes can blend, meaning a go-with-the-flow discoverer might also possess the cultural capital needed to avoid tourist traps.

Despite this poten9al for blending, our research suggests that tourismifica9on-the prolifera9on of inauthen9c or low-quality establishments-arises predominantly from purely gowith-the-flow or habitual discovery. Iconic sites like Barcelona's Sagrada Familia or Brussels' Grand Place are typically surrounded by global fast-food chains and businesses that masquerade as authen9c local experiences (Ganzaroli, De Noni, & Van Baalen, 2017). Discoverers in habitual or gowith-the-flow modes, who oeen prefer an unplanned approach, can be easily lured by these convenient op9ons that cater to high foot traffic and brand recogni9on.

div.head: Mul7ple factors influence which discovery mode is adopted
div.p: This study emphasizes that-while various models and theories of informa9on behavior and decision-making shed valuable light on urban discovery-no single approach fully captures the complexity of how individuals discover a city. Consistent with Lepp and Gibson (2008), and Tran and Ralston (2006), our study confirms the important role of personality, par9cularly openness to experience and need for cogni9ve closure, in shaping discovery behavior. However, our findings show that the expression of these traits depends on the situa9on.

In line with previous research (Lehto et al., 2006;Tse & Cro8s, 2005;Vogt & Fesenmaier, 1998), we observe that familiarity with a city s9mulates novelty seeking, as captured by the go-withthe-flow mode. Our findings extend this literature by revealing that familiarity not only encourages spontaneous explora9on but also enhances social and flaneur discovery, since travelers possess richer background knowledge and stronger social connec9ons within familiar environments.

Conversely, unfamiliarity amplifies a traveler's desire for cogni9ve closure, resul9ng in more reliance on instrumental-ra9onal decision-making, while significant cultural unfamiliarity triggers habitual discovery, exemplified by travelers seeking out familiar comfort foods from global chains.

Furthermore, our findings support Kozak's (2010) claim that interpersonal constraints increase decision-making complexity in travel groups. Heterogeneous groups, facing diverse interests and physical constraints, typically favor instrumental-ra9onal decision-making. For example, one par9cipant described carefully researching loca9ons to accommodate mobility constraints. Habitual discovery also arises in these groups due to preferences for predictable environments, especially among families with children who value familiar, comfor9ng experiences. In contrast, homogeneous travel par7es rely more on shared tastes and intui9ons, enabling spontaneous affec9ve decisionmaking typical of go-with-the-flow or flaneur discovery.

Consistent with Moore et al. (2012) and Tse and Cro8s (2005), our findings highlight 7me constraints as influen9al contextual factors. Limited 9me and unforeseen changes in planning leads travelers to seek predictable experiences, hence adop9ng habitual discovery mode. Conversely, ample 7me s9mulates spontaneous explora9on, consistent with go-with-the-flow mode.
Age also emerged as a significant factor influencing discovery modes, paralleling findings by Kim et al. (2015). Younger travelers, seeking efficiency and convenience, oeen prefer instrumental-

div.head: Prac;cal implica;ons
div.p: Besides theore9cal contribu9ons, our research offers valuable guidance to pla3orm providers about how to design pla3orms that meet a variety of user needs and how hospitality service providers best present themselves on these pla3orms.

div.head: Prac7cal implica7ons for industrializa7on and business strategy
div.p: Following Leiper (2008, We understand tourism not as a single industry but as a collec9on of industries). Leiper conceptualizes industrializa9on as the combina9on of collabora9on and specific targe9ng to the same customer group (Leiper et al., 2008). The rise of digital pla3orms has introduced new industrializa9on strategies, from collabora9ng with influencers to managing online ra9ngs.
