In this context, our findings suggest that industrializa9on is most effec9ve when targeted not just to customers, but to their specific discovery modes. Different discovery modes can be swayed by different industrializa9on strategies, leading to different urban a8rac9on industries.

Instrumental-ra9onal discoverers will be most effec9vely a8racted by a high volume of posi9ve ra9ngs on review pla3orms. Strategies to achieve this include offering incen9ves for posi9ve reviews or, as some have noted, even pos9ng fake ones (Filieri, 2016). An alterna9ve strategy could be to develop an independent review organiza9on to build trust with this discerning group.

Go-with-the-flow discoverers, on the other hand, are more effec9vely a8racted by eyecatching markers that trigger their impulsivity. This requires collabora9on through though3ul urban planning and nudging people to discover different parts of the city.

The social discovery mode is best targeted by s9mula9ng people to talk about the urban a8rac9on. This can be done, for example, by cul9va9ng posi9ve word-of-mouth, collabora9ng with social media influencers to make and distribute content about the urban a8rac9on, and by crea9ng an instagrammable décor.

Flaneurs, on the other hand, are best swayed by an interes9ng story behind the urban a8rac9on. This can be done by integra9ng the history of the loca9on into the service provided and by collabora9ng with historians, writers, or documentary makers.
Lastly, people in habitual mode are best swayed by familiarity, brand recogni9on, and customer loyalty programs.

div.head: Prac7cal implica7ons for plaEorm providers
div.p: Our findings show that the discovery mode influences which pla3orm features and content are u9lized and valued. For instance, when users explore in instrumental-ra9onal mode, filter func9onali9es and access to reviews and ra9ngs are important. In this mode, individuals are looking for high afforded diagnos9city, i.e., how well a pla3orm affords to "systema9cally and effec9vely
search and compare relevant alterna9ves un9l reaching a final choice" (Yi et al., 2010, p. 4).

Conversely, for individuals in flaneur mode, reviews and ra9ngs hold li8le value. Instead, they are drawn to detailed background informa9on and resources that allow a deeper explora9on of urban a8rac9ons' history, authen9city, and an aesthe9c presenta9on on the pla3orm. We discuss the prac9cal implica9ons of our findings more extensively in the a8ached impact statement.

div.head: Limita;ons and future studies
div.p: Although our data was primarily collected pre-COVID-19, we observe that our findings remain relevant today. The abstrac9on of our discovery modes allows to incorporate new emerging discovery prac9ces (e.g., the role of TikTok in urban discovery). Furthermore, our most recent interviews corroborate our earlier results. Specifically, we iden9fied few new codes, and those we did find did not challenge our typology. Instead, they added addi9onal nuance, enriching the framework.

While our qualita9ve methodology was well-suited for this exploratory study, it imposes limits on the generalizability of the results. Although we iden9fy five discovery modes, we cannot es9mate their prevalence. To address this, future research could employ diary studies, where par9cipants log discovered urban a8rac9ons and their discovery process. These could be coupled with interviews to gain insights into decision-making and the experience of visi9ng these sites.

Future studies could expand upon our findings using quan9ta9ve methods to further explore and validate these discovery modes and their contextual rela9onships. For instance, experimental designs could simulate specific scenarios-such as planning a birthday dinner-to inves9gate preferred content and the primary mo9va9ons behind urban a8rac9on selec9on in such contexts.

Addi9onally, our findings can poten9ally be generalized to other domains. While our focus has been on hospitality and tourism, the discovery modes we propose may have broader relevance and could be adapted to markets such as e-commerce or video-on-demand.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: This ar9cle adapts and extends Leiper's tourist a8rac9on systems framework to the context of modern urban discovery. Using a grounded theory approach, we developed an exploratory typology of five dis9nct discovery modes. Instrumental-ra9onal discoverers seek certainty and systema9cally compare a8rac9ons, while habitual discoverers favor familiarity over the op9mal choice. In contrast, playful discoverers value the journey more than the des9na9on. This group encompasses go-with-the-flow travelers, who explore spontaneously; social discoverers, guided by social interac9ons; and flaneurs, who cul9vate a roman9c rela9onship with the city.
Our typology's main contribu9on is its demonstra9on that urban discovery is not a single behavior but a spectrum, shaped by a nuanced interplay of personal, social, and contextual factors.
We iden9fied key psychological determinants-such as openness to experience, need for cogni9ve closure, and social trust-that predict which discovery mode a person will adopt in a given situa9on.

Furthermore, while acknowledging the importance of peer-review pla3orms, our findings challenge the narra9ve of digital dominance. We show that travelers con9nue to rely on a diverse range of informa9on prac9ces, from talking with locals and reading guidebooks to simply wandering through the city. By iden9fying and detailing these varied modes, par9cularly underexplored behaviors like the flaneur, this study integrates fragmented research and offers a more holis9c founda9on for understanding how people discover the contemporary city.

Par9cipant 23 underlines the benefits of this approach: "it's easier to figure out everything in advance so that you get the most out of your visit." Once ra9onal-instrumental discoverers se8le on a plan, they s9ck to it, valuing predictability and certainty above spontaneous decisions: "yes, I really do follow the recommenda9on strictly. Then I'm sure I won't be disappointed by going somewhere else." (Par9cipant 10). Their quest for predictability leads them to leverage remote access affordances extensively, for instance making reserva9ons and buying 9ckets online beforehand.

(2009), reflec9ng their desire for authen9c urban explora9on.Moreover, our study breaks new ground by explicitly highligh9ng affec9ve factors-par9cularly mood and charm-as pivotal elements shaping discovery behaviors. A posi9ve mood fosters openness to experience and encourages spontaneous, affec9ve decision-making. Conversely, nega9ve moods such as discomfort or fa9gue elevate cogni9ve closure, steering travelers toward instrumental-ra9onal or habitual modes. Charm, as noted by par9cipants, significantly enhances affec9ve decision-making and prompts spontaneous explora9on.By integra9ng these personal, social, contextual, demographic, and affec9ve dimensions, our grounded typology of discovery modes deepens exis9ng theore9cal understandings of tourism decision-making. It reveals how travelers fluidly shie between modes based on internal predisposi9ons and external condi9ons, underscoring the complexity and context-dependency of urban explora9on behaviors.

Conversely, unfamiliarity enhances the desire for cogni9ve closure, making instrumental-ra9onal discovery more appealing: "If you go to a new city and something is popular and scores really well on TripAdvisor and if you go and look on Instagram it also looks really nice, even if it's popular I'll go there. Moreover, cultural unfamiliarity promotes habitual discovery, as Par9cipant 126 explains: "Certainly if you go to a country that is very unfamiliar, let's say Vietnam or Thailand, aPer a while you had enough, and you just want comfort food. You want to go to a McDonalds, KFC or Burger King."
